fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:fullName: ISO/IEC 14496-3:2001. Information technology -- Coding of audio-visual objects -- Part 3: Audio. Formal name for the relevant part of the MPEG-4 standard; note that this part covers several types of audio coding including Advanced Audio Coding. Common name: AAC.

fdd:description.p: Perceptual audio encoding format designed for efficient distribution of sound files over moderate bandwidth connections; may be used at higher data rates for better fidelity. AAC_MP4 compression is a further refinement of AAC_MP2. AAC_MP4 is an object-based coding standard; decoders for AAC_MP2 may not be able to read AAC_MP4.

The specification defines various object types and profiles; see Notes. Video-capable iPods and iPhones specify video files for which the audio appears to be audio-object-limited rather than profile-compliant; see AAC_MP4_LC. The compiler of this page welcomes comments on this detail.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Perceptual audio encoding format designed for efficient distribution of sound files over moderate bandwidth connections; may be used at higher data rates for better fidelity. AAC_MP4 compression is a further refinement of AAC_MP2.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: Generally used for final-state, end-user delivery.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Various AAC_MP4 profiles, not documented at this time; see Notes.

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: MPEG-4 File Format, V.2, with Advanced Audio Coding
MPEG-4 File Format, Version 2, with Visual Coding
MPEG-4 File Format, Version 2, with Advanced Video Coding

MPEG-4 File Format, V.2, with AVC, High Profile
MPEG-4 File Format, V.2, with AVC, High 10 Profile

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Other file or wrapper formats, not documented at this time

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: See the Library of Congress Recommended Formats Statement for format preferences for audio works.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Open standard. Developed through ISO technical program JTC 1/SC 29 for coding of audio, picture, multimedia and hypermedia information by Working Group 11 (WG11) aka the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG).
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: ISO/IEC 14496-3:2001. Information technology -- Coding of audio-visual objects -- Part 3: Audio. Later editions were published in 2005 and 2009; these have not yet been assessed for this description. See also MP4_FF_2.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:adoption: Some adoption for World Wide Web dissemination and playback on specialized devices. QTA_AAC, QuickTime AAC, is used in Apple's iTunes service. Software tools exist for encoding and decoding.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: Royalties are due on the sale of AAC encoders and/or decoders; no use-based fees; information at Via Licensing. Page available via an Internet Archive capture from April 4, 2016.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Depends upon algorithms and tools to read; requires sophistication to build tools.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: Technical (coding) information is contained in the headers for the "frames" that make up the bitstream. See also MP4_FF_2.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:externalDependencies: Surround sound requires appropriate amplifier and loudspeakers or headphone.

fdd:soundQF.fdd:fidelity: Moderate to good, given that this is a format for compression. All commentators state that at a given data rate, the quality of AAC_MP4 surpasses AAC_MP2 and is significantly better than MP3_ENC.
fdd:soundQF.fdd:channels: AAC has provision for up to 48 channels, and supports 5.1 (and 7.1?) surround sound.

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: Used for raw bitstream; The File Extension Source associates the aac extension with AAC_ADIF, the file format for MPEG-2 AAC. In any case, most AAC files carry an extension that depends upon the selected wrapper; for example, see MP4_FF_2 (mp4, m4a) and QTA_AAC (m4p).

fdd:internetMediaType.fdd:note: Depends upon wrapper; for example, see MP4_FF_2 and QTA_AAC.
For MP4 File with Audio but without Visual Presentati From IANA and RFC 4337, MIME Type Registration for MPEG-4

fdd:values.fdd:note: No PRONOM PUID as of April 2022
See https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q337594. Does not distinguish between profiles of AAC (so covers both MPEG-2 and MPEG-4)

fdd:notes.fdd:general:
The sets of options in AAC_MP4 are more extensive than those provided in the specification for AAC_MP2. Eight profiles are associated with AAC_MP4 audio, each of which may present sound at various levels:
Speech Audio Profile
Synthetic Audio Profile
Scalable Audio Profile
Main Audio Profile
High Quality Audio Profile
Low Delay Audio Profile
Natural Audio Profile
Mobile Audio Internet Working Profile These profiles are described in the specification on pages 15-20. In a given file, the profile and the level chosen for use are indicated by embedded metadata, not documented at this time. The profiles are associated with audio objects.
Additional profiles are listed in the Wikipedia article Advanced Audio Coding (consulted October 22, 2014): AAC Profile (defined 2003), High Efficiency AAC Profile (2003), and High Efficiency AAC v2 Profile (2006).
There is an AAC_MP4 object called Low Complexity (AAC_MP4_LC), which is comparable to the AAC_MP2 Low Complexity profile. The compiler of this page seeks more information about this matter; Comments welcome.

fdd:citation.fdd:specReference: ISO/IEC 14496-3:2001 Information technology -- Coding of audio-visual objects -- Part 3: Audio. (Note: later editions from 2005 and 2009 have also been published.)

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: "MP3 and AAC Explained" is a 1999 article by Karlheinz Brandenburg, Fraunhofer Institute, Erlangen, Germany. It has good detail but with a focus on AAC_MP2.

fdd:urlReference.comment: As published in proceedings of the 17th AES International Conference on High Quality Audio Coding, 1999, Sept 2-5.

fdd:urlReference.tag: AAC-LC: High performance music distribution - Fraunhofer Institute

fdd:urlReference.comment: A previous version of the above page from the Fraunhofer Institute, as it appeared on October 6, 2014. Available via Internet Archive.
